title: Atlético de Rafaela
text:
Asociación Mutual Social y Deportiva Atlético de Rafaela usually known simply as Atlético de Rafaela is an <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="sports%20club">sports club</a> from the city of <a href="Rafaela">Rafaela</a>, in <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Province">Santa Fe Province</a>. The club is mostly known for its professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> team, which currently plays in <a href="Primera%20B%20Nacional">Primera B Nacional</a>, the second division of the <a href="Argentine%20football%20league%20system">Argentine football league system</a>. It is popularly known in Argentina and other southamerican countries for its nickname "La Crema".
Apart from football, other sports and activities practised at the institution are <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="chess">chess</a>, <a href="field%20hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="artistic%20gymnastics">artistic gymnastics</a>, <a href="paddle%20tennis">paddle tennis</a>, <a href="roller%20skating">roller skating</a>, <a href="skeet%20shooting">skeet shooting</a>, <a href="swimming%20%28sport%29">swimming</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a> and <a href="volleyball">volleyball</a>.
History.
Under the name "Club Atlético Argentino de Rafaela", the club was founded in the city of Rafaela, <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Province">Santa Fe Province</a> in 1907. In 1915 the name was changed to "Club Atlético de Rafaela". The Monumental de Barrio Alberdi concrete stadium was erected in 1951.
The club was turned into a non-profit organization in 1988, and renamed "Asociación Mutual Social y Deportiva Atlético de Rafaela" ("Social and Sport Association Rafaela Athletic"). Only a year later Rafaela reached the second division after defeating <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Ledesma">Atlético Ledesma</a> by 3–0 with goals scored by López (20', 30') and Poelman (35').
Atlético de Rafaela played in the second division for 14 years until the team won the <a href="Apertura">Apertura</a> 2002 and the <a href="Clausura">Clausura</a> 2003 to finally reach the <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina">first division</a>. After losing the "<a href="2003-2004%20in%20Argentine%20football%23%26quot%3BPromoci%C3%B3n%26quot%3B%20Playoff">promoción</a>" against <a href="Hurac%C3%A1n%20de%20Tres%20Arroyos">Huracán de Tres Arroyos</a>, Atlético de Rafaela was relegated to the second division again.
The following season Atlético lost its chance to return to the first division, after losing the "<a href="2003-2004%20in%20Argentine%20football%23%26quot%3BPromoci%C3%B3n%26quot%3B%20Playoff">promoción</a>", against <a href="Argentinos%20Juniors">Argentinos Juniors</a>.
In 2009 Rafaela earned another chance to return to the Primera División via a <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina%202008%E2%80%9309%23Relegation.2Fpromotion%20playoffs">playoff</a> against <a href="Gimnasia%20y%20Esgrima%20de%20La%20Plata">Gimnasia y Esgrima de La Plata</a>. After winning the first final 3–0, Rafaela lost the second match by the same score (0–3) and had to stay in the second division once again.
Atlético de Rafaela fans are referred to as "Cremosos" or "Celestes", and the people that follows the team everywhere are known as "La Barra de los Trapos" .
The club also has an <a href="Aut%C3%B3dromo%20Ciudad%20de%20Rafaela">important car racing circuit</a> since 1919, which hosts many competitions including the <a href="Turismo%20Carretera">Turismo Carretera</a> (since 1941) and the <a href="TC%202000">TC 2000</a> (since 1983).
On the 21st of May 2011, after defeating <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Tucum%C3%A1n">Atlético Tucumán</a> 2–0 with goals scored by <a href="Oscar%20Carniello">Carniello</a> and <a href="Alexis%20Castro%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201984%29">Aldana</a>, they earned a place back in the <a href="Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">first division</a> for the 2011–12 season.
